item.title: Do-it-yourself rain bench by Second Rain
item.description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cdg6Jwxb9bM Chris Russell Published on Dec 2, 2009 System demonstrated in the video shows how a small pond it used to store overflow, and how the rain bench diverter/ filter system works. We just built a rain harvesting system using the do-it-yourself rain bench by Second Rain. We put it in our yard about 12 feet from the Saving Rain diverter that is in the downspout on the corner of our house.

item.title: Our Complete Rain Water System Explained
item.description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EsxuT-kgHPg Bill and Rosa Off Grid Published on Aug 11, 2015 In this video I cover the complete fresh water system for our cabin. We harvest rainwater for our needs. We use gutter system on the house to dump into five 55 gallon barrels then into a 250 gallon tote. We then transfer it into other storage when we can. Also we transfer it into our main 250 gallon tote to supply our home.

item.title: rainwater harvesting combined with slow sand filter
item.description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BaCOlRlw3K4 edvac1 dave Published on Feb 17, 2010 Capture the rain! (Now legal in Washington state). A quick look at roof water harvesting using a slow sand filter combined with a diverter. This is an overview of the procedure and a demonstration of a working system. An instructional video on how to build a system can be found here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S-_RDB… As of September 18, 2016 this filter is still running and producing clean water.

item.title: 15,000 Gallon Rainwater Harvesting System
item.description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1rKiSD4A1K4 EasyOn Gutter Guard is used to keep leaves, redwood tree needles and roof sand grit out of the gutter and a huge 15,000 gallon rainwater catchment system for a homeowner in California. EasyOn are Do-It-Yourself (DIY) gutter guards that can be installed on any gutter and roof type. They are made from a fine surgical stainless steel micromesh and anodized aluminum frame. 2,500 holes per square inch keeps out all the fine debris.
